comments.body:
h2. Testing Notes

I wanted to cover the code change, and how to verify/validate the fix. Essentially I modified the global networking parsing to use a list to store the mappings of NC IP -> hostname.  This mapping is created the first time the file is parsed, and will only update (eg make the DNS lookups again) if another NC is added to the system. 

I would do the following to verify the fix:
* turn logging to TRACE on the NC, you will see logs printing out the IP to hostname mapping:
{code}
2015-04-14 09:49:02 TRACE 000014546 gni_hostnames_print      | Cached Hostname Info:
2015-04-14 09:49:02 TRACE 000014546 gni_hostnames_print      | IP Address: 192.168.1.91 Hostname: 192.168.1.91
{code}
* Another thing to look for is that we're getting 'hits' when parsing the nodes, you should see 'bsearch hit' in the logs like below:
{code}
2015-04-14 09:49:07 TRACE 000014546 evaluate_xpath_element   | 1 results after evaluated expression /network-data/configuration/property[@name='clusters']/*/property[@name='nodes']/node
2015-04-14 09:49:07 TRACE 000014546 evaluate_xpath_element   |  RESULT 0: 192.168.1.91
2015-04-14 09:49:07 TRACE 000014546 gni_populate             | Found 1 Nodes in the config
2015-04-14 09:49:07 TRACE 000014546 gni_populate             | after function: 0: 192.168.1.91
2015-04-14 09:49:07 TRACE 000014546 gni_hostnames_get_hostna | bsearch hit: 192.168.1.91
{code}
* I would also test this where there IS and IS NOT a DNS server. As you can see my system does not have a DNS server, although I did test in the lab to verify that the name lookup is working and a hostname shows up in the mapping. 

At a lower level you can use tcpdump to verify that the DNS queries are only done once upon startup and should pretty much be non-existent after the first iteration. Remember that by default the parse of the XML happens every 5 seconds. So 15-20 seconds of tcpdump is enough to verify all is good:
{code}
[root@nc1 sbin]# tcpdump -vvv -s 0 -l -n port 53
{code}

The other thing to pay attention to is memory usage, I ran the change through valgrind and there were no memory leaks. 

This change also impacts the CC, but to a lesser degree as during my testing of the CC it didn't have any nodes to do reverse lookups for. The change for the CC is slightly different in that we rebuild the hostname mapping every iteration, which will reduce lookups dramatically but not all the way. Again in my testing it looks like the CC does not have to perform reverse lookups on the NC ips.

I am seeing the LOG entries and tcpdump looks good:
{code}
[root@b-20 eucalyptus]# grep gni_hostnames_print eucanetd.log
2015-04-20 18:32:19 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | Cached Hostname Info: 
2015-04-20 18:32:19 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | IP Address: 10.111.5.197 Hostname: b-20.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
2015-04-20 18:32:24 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | Cached Hostname Info: 
2015-04-20 18:32:24 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | IP Address: 10.111.5.197 Hostname: b-20.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
2015-04-20 18:32:29 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | Cached Hostname Info: 
2015-04-20 18:32:29 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | IP Address: 10.111.5.197 Hostname: b-20.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
2015-04-20 18:32:34 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | Cached Hostname Info: 
2015-04-20 18:32:34 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | IP Address: 10.111.5.197 Hostname: b-20.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
2015-04-20 18:32:39 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | Cached Hostname Info: 
2015-04-20 18:32:39 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | IP Address: 10.111.5.197 Hostname: b-20.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
2015-04-20 18:32:44 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | Cached Hostname Info: 
2015-04-20 18:32:44 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | IP Address: 10.111.5.197 Hostname: b-20.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
2015-04-20 18:32:49 TRACE 000026194 gni_hostnames_print      | Cached Hostname Info: 
[root@b-20 eucalyptus]# tcpdump -vvv -s 0 -l -n port 53
tcpdump: listening on br0, link-type EN10MB (Ethernet), capture size 65535 bytes
{code}
